channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: "Little lands on the borders of a great empire were always hateful to the lords of the great empire." https://t.co/IZ8OhW99qw

“Most of her friends, who seemed to her ordinarily hard-working, anxious, and hopeful, people, could lay claim to being disowned or prayed for, in some disappointed home. —Alice Munro, “Spelling” #SundaySentence @MunroQuotes
The democratic possibilities of web publishing? In 2003, Christopher Lydon (@RadioOpenSource) and @DaveWiner put down some markers on the topic in this republished audio. https://t.co/g6qBwtD6DC

“To remember a battle in which he has taken part,” [Louis Simpson] wrote in 1964, “a man must make himself innocent again — innocent of newspapers, books and movies. He must remember his actual life, the life of the body. Everything else is journalism.” https://t.co/RkgHPQsB5o

The @January6thCmte showed on Thursday that public discourse is a damned serious matter, far more serious than many politicians and journalists understand. And @FoxNews confirmed that their goal is not truth but victory to be won through the arts of deception and distraction. https://t.co/v4jAcEz9n3
Image: Initial D: The Fool with Two Demons (detail) in a psalter, illuminations by the Master of the Ingeborg Psalter, after 1205. The J. Paul Getty Museum, Ms. 66, fol. 56. Via Elisabeth Morrison.

The @January6thCmte showed that public discourse is a damned serious matter, far more serious than many politicians and journalists understand. @FoxNews confirmed on Thursday that their goal is not truth but victory to be achieved through the arts of deception and distraction.
Dead cities, the reporter said. (A poem from this week's news.) https://t.co/hXoqc2VM37
Judging by the Fox response, we are a society that subsists on cartoons. We could hardly be in deeper trouble than that. https://t.co/rCGxycFNlO
The story of maturity is a long story, if we're lucky. https://t.co/F8fPVhSTCx
Last night: Fox “news” people rebutting a report they hadn’t seen yet as it was being broadcast live on the other channels. https://t.co/0fIFFAGbqz

Not just hearing music any time. Exploring music, and choosing the explorer’s path for oneself, and moment by moment calling the tune for one’s own life. A thing never seen before. https://t.co/MG73EYWL3W
Alternative narrative already underway on that one channel now. https://t.co/mTCaxUYRJT
Publish this list as soon as possible. https://t.co/KMxDwxd83M
Web3: " I honestly don't think such a thing exists." Brief thread. https://t.co/iyYYs6vYFP

Odd @NPR lingo thing these days: using present tense verbs to describe past events. Here, the reporter asks questions about past actions using present tense verbs even when the interviewee speaks of her past life with past tense verbs. Weird tic, @NPR. https://t.co/Qelwxz7yTP
“We made the world we’re living in and we have to make it over,” said James Baldwin. https://t.co/1qq61Ly6TT

“To change peoples’ minds about guns, we must give them reason to trust. This means investing in public systems that give people cause to believe that they will be appropriately protected so they might loosen their defensive grip on guns and embrace gun laws that protect us all.” https://t.co/SL6qrH1dQw https://t.co/slx9QqFxeR
I read and reread the tweet in question a couple weeks ago and couldn’t discover what could possibly have triggered the content warning from @Twitter. So I appealed. https://t.co/ZwUkVibekD

Journalists on air tend to emphasize the first syllable, saying “PROUDboys” and making it sound like it’s bursting out of loudspeakers at a rally. Slow down, just say “. . . the group that calls itself . . the . . proud . . boys.”

“It just exacerbates all the conspiratorial stuff that we have swirling around and sets us on a dangerous course. It further corrodes our ability to be grounded in the same empirical reality.” —Whitney Phillips / @WPhillips49 https://t.co/Vjb0deb0ZO

One excellent thing about the @RuralWriting Institute is that it suggests a model for developing and celebrating writing from any less-heard-from groups and places in society. @herdyshepherd1 @theshepherdswi1 @kathrynaalto https://t.co/5reY46PPCo

“At the end of the talk, of which I understood frustratingly little, Derrida asked a question that took about 20 minutes to formulate. Laclau’s response was of equal length.” The question from the title is maybe answered behind the PAYWALL. https://t.co/Sx5xAhkM52
Good to see @TeenVogue planting the idea among young readers that environmental emergencies can largely be the result of human activity. https://t.co/MlrJxWQpTh

"While the Dust Bowl, a largely man-made environmental emergency, lays bare the destruction humans can wreak on the environment, it also shows how large-scale collective response can help mitigate environmental disaster . . ." https://t.co/prRQjPN0Ke

I'm very fond of this entire poster. I wish we could add a pithy line or two at the bottom that indicated that these worthy and essential bundles of knowledge-attitudes-skills only give citizens much of a chance of success if they know how to . . . 1/2 https://t.co/EKh833heuA
. . . how to affiliate with others, amplify the voices of others, and defend institutions from being hollowed out, how to make the powerful take notice of the reach and staying power in citizens' voices because citizens have done the work to build public voices of that kind. 2/2
